metadata.value: a  TREND IN PARKING  IS UNDERGROUND  I  -, ___  Survey of Traffic in 24 Cities  Reveas Opinion Is Divided  on the Use of Meters  |P? . H. 7UJ H Uj  A survey of traffic conditions in  twenty-four of the nation"s largest,  cities has revealed that a consider-"  able number of them are providing,  underground,   off-the-street  park-;  ing    facilities;    that    opinion    is  equay divided on the use of parking meter, and that a majority of  them have estabished some form  of municipal contro to cordinate  the  activities of various city departments.  This was revealed yesterday by  the Commerce and Industry  Association of New York, which conducted the survey as the basis for  recommendations to the City Council here. The cities covered in the  survey were Chicago, Phiadephia,  Boston, Detroit, Ceveand, Kansas  City, Pittsburgh, San Francisco,  os Angees, Buffao, Rochester,  Houston, Newark, Atanta, Memphis, Providence, New Oreans,  Seatte, Indianapois. St. Pau, San  Antonio, Minneapois, Toedo and  Oakand. .  San Francisco has constructed;  a 1,700-car parking- garage, four.  stories in depth, beneath a city  park in the business area. It is  privately operated. Detroit, by ref-.  erendum, voted this year to construct a. 1,000-car garage beneath  a city street, to be municipayi  operated. os Angees is consider-1  ing the construction of a 2,700-car  garage underneath a park. CIeve-|  and permits the parking of 700  cars in an underground exhibition  ha, when the space is not otherwise occupied.  Tweve cities, among them Chi  cago, Boston, Phiadephia and De-;  troit, reported that they maintain:"  some   kind   of   municipal   traffic"I  contro      commission.      generaly  such commissions are empowered  to make surveys and recommendations to the city egisative  body,  but   Boston   and   Rochester   give  their   commissions    authority    to  make minor traffic reguations.  Every city surveyed, except  Memphis, admitted serious traffic  problems. Most of them held this  problem is accentuated by narrow  streets and by ack of sufficient  off-street parking facilities.  Seventeen of the cities studied  reported their difficuties were accentuated by concentrations of:  trucks in their busy areas, and  fourteen of them found pedestrian  cross-wak congestion further deayed traffic. Five cities had tried  a limited number of overhead pedestrian crosswaks with varying  success.  Fifteen of the cities prohibit  curbstone parking entirey in their  main business sections, and limit it  to one ide of the street in less  congested areas.
